posts.name: Hiago Obalero Santos Araujo
posts.cooked: During our manifold prototype testing, our engine cables came loose shortly after the engine made a high-pitched noise.  If anyone has any idea what it could be, it might be helpful.  We are using a 40A fuse, a NEO 550 motor and a Spark Max. (The motor and spark cables are of different thicknesses and are connected by a WAGO connector).  Here is a video of the moment of the incident, look at the cables in the background of the video.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
It’s hard to see what’s happening in the video, but it does look strange.  Was there any bad smell from the motor (engine)?  It it any harder to spin the motor by hand now?  Did it stop working when you reconnected things?

It’s fairly easy to burn out a NEO550, but if this happens, there is a bad smell and sometimes smoke.  It’s a very good idea when using a NEO550 to configure a current limit (say 20Amps for prototyping) in the SPARK MAX.  Or, use a regular NEO.

It could be the wires got caught in something, but I don’t see anything like this happening in the video.  I would not use a different NEO550 until you know what happened in the video, in case something bad happened to the one you were using.

It is difficult to see exactly exactly what happened; was the high pitched noise associated with an increase in speed and did the speed change in Rev Hardware client?

You seem to have pulleys mounted directly on the motor bell. These are not meant to take sideloading so potentially that could have been part of the issue.

Was there vibration when it happened? I suspect that because the Wago connectors fit the SparkMAX cables they slip off of the motor when there is vibration because they are too large.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.custom_user_title: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.name: David Ellers
posts.cooked:
If you are using the 12AWG WAGO connector, it is rated for 20 Amps.  If the connection is getting hot, the spring tension may be affected.  This could cause the wire to release (I would need to personally test this).  Things that effect this includes strip length on the wire, wire gauge, Amps on the circuit, number of conductors making contact inside the WAGO connector.

Put a ferrule on the 14AWG wire coming from the NEO 550.

Put a current limit on your Spark Max set to 20 Amps.

If you are drawing more than 20Amps, switch to Anderson Connectors

Test and post results.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: Please post a close-up photo showing the ends of the wires that came loose, without the WAGO connector installed on it.

posts.name: Ryan Du
posts.cooked: I don’t know much but it did look like there was an issue with the wago connections but it looks like a really sudden disconnect like the wires were pulled out of the wago.

posts.name: Brian Rozmierski
posts.cooked:
Need more info, as the post above indicate. That said, if this was a Wago 221 connector, absent a very significant force, which is not apparent to me in the video, those wires should not be able to come out like that. I looked but was not able to find any testing documentation or videos showing the pull-force required to remove a wire with the lever latched.

As time goes on I grow more wary of these Wagos / Lever nuts in general, especially in high amperage situations. I’ve seen them melt in robots, and I’ve seen them on CAN buses cause odd problems.

Nearly all of the failures I’ve seen can ultimately be traced back to useage contrary to the manufacturer’s instructions. First, with wire strip-length and insertion depth, second with amperage ratings on the connector itself.

I strongly believe if you use one of these connectors improperly, you’re going to have a bad day. On a motor lead and you may well melt one (I have pictures). On a CAN bus and loose/bad connections will plague you for quite a while.

Also, the 221 in-line is listed as rated for 30A, however due to a quirk of the rules last year, and REV (a VENDOR as defined in the rules) has listed tham as applicable for 12ga wire, they were legal with 40A breakers. I do not know if the rules will change for this year to limit them to something more akin to the manufacturer’s rating, however.

Regardless, I urge all teams to carefully follow the manufacturer’s guidance in proper preparation and wire insertion when using these connectors.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
bdaroz:

very significant force [?]

There was very significant force as the white conductor can be seen pulled taut at about 5 seconds, just before the failure at 8 seconds.

That connector on white may have been able to hold that much tension in normal circumstances but …

it can be seen resting atop of a seemingly bare splice connector for the black conductor that may have been poorly crimped resulting in it getting very hot. We can see that the left motor runs sporadically - almost not at all - likely because of that poor splice.

I suggest that it was the lack of a quality, insulated connection on the black conductor as the root cause of the failure.

This was an old question but still pertinent - good, insulated connections are vital and useful even for prototypes.

posts.name: Antonio
posts.cooked:
I don’t have any experience with NEO 550’s specifically, but it appears to be a mechanical issue that pulled the wires out of the connector. You can see the polycarbonate deflect away from the camera at the time of the disconnect.

The motor starts up and begins to spin the belt and then the belt stops and the high pitch noise begins. The noise sounds more like high rpm than a stall to me. I suspect the motor became disconnected from the pulley. Likely the motor housing became disconnected from the shaft. The motor was then allowed to spin to a high rpm. Something then bound up and stopped the motor, dumping its kinetic energy into deforming the polycarbonate.

I believe the motor is damaged and you should remove it to investigate further. It may not be obvious if the housing as broke loose.
